snippet: Guanabara Bay, the venue for the 2016 sailing and windsurfing events, is so foul that a biologist called it “a latrine” and a sailor said he had encountered bodies.
abstract: Rio de Janeiro's polluted Guanabara Bay has become focal point for criticism as Brazil struggles to prepare for 2016 Olympic Games; waters, infamous for their sewage, trash and even animal carcasses, will nonetheless be site of all sailing and windsurfing events at the games; well-financed efforts to clean up the bay have fallen short for decades.

byline.original: By SIMON ROMERO and CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
byline.contributor: Simon Romero reported from Rio de Janeiro, and Christopher Clarey from Boston. Miriam Wells contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro.

lead_paragraph: Guanabara Bay, the venue for the 2016 sailing and windsurfing events, is so foul that a biologist called it “a latrine” and a sailor said he had encountered bodies.

headline.main: Note to Olympic Sailors: Don’t Fall in Rio’s Water
headline.print_headline: Note to Olympic Sailors: Don’t Fall in Rio’s Water
